G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 5.proposition: This action is brought in the Housing Court Department, Springfield Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3 and 5, which grant the Housing Court jurisdiction over civil actions involving residential housing, including claims arising out of landlord‑tenant relationships and breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 4.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Electricity is a basic and essential service and utility that must be provided and maintained by a residential landlord in Massachusetts as part of the implied warranty of habitability and statutory duties under the State Sanitary Code and related regulations.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.351.proposition: Electricity is a basic and essential service and utility that must be provided and maintained by a residential landlord in Massachusetts as part of the implied warranty of habitability and statutory duties under the State Sanitary Code and related regulations.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and a landlord who does so “shall be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: The State Sanitary Code and related regulations require that landlords provide and maintain safe and functional electrical service.

105 C.M.R. 410.200 et seq..proposition: The State Sanitary Code and related regulations require that landlords provide and maintain safe and functional electrical service.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, is read into every residential tenancy in Massachusetts, whether written or oral.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion applies and discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not state that this statutory covenant is read into every residential tenancy, whether written or oral. The court analyzes what conduct can constitute a breach and the nature of the interference required, without addressing the question of whether § 14’s covenant is implied in all residential leases. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific breadth of the claimed proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. This section also confers on the Superior and District Courts the authority in equity to restrain violations of its provisions. Id.  

The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, is read into every residential tenancy in Massachusetts, whether written or oral.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion applies and enforces G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet enjoyment provisions to this residential tenant (a tenant at will), but it does not state or discuss that the statutory covenant is implied in “every” residential tenancy, nor does it distinguish between written and oral tenancies. The case assumes the statute applies to this tenant and focuses on whether lack of financial ability is a defense and what remedies are available, not on the breadth of the statute’s application across all residential tenancies. Thus it is consistent with, but does not itself establish, the broad proposition claimed.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: It was claimed that the defendants had violated those portions of G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, which impose civil liability on a landlord “who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish . . . heat. . . or . . . who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . .” … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when there is a serious or substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the standard for liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14. While its main holding concerns the need for at least negligent conduct (not strict liability), the court reiterates and applies the established framework from Simon and Cruz that § 14 is breached when the landlord’s fault-based acts or omissions foreseeably interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, which matches the proposition’s description of a serious/substantial interference caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “In Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. … We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when there is a serious or substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The court explicitly reframes the covenant of quiet enjoyment away from requiring intent and toward liability where the landlord’s conduct or omissions naturally and probably cause a substantial deprivation of the tenant’s use of the premises. It holds that the landlords breached the implied covenant by permitting and failing to control severe late-night noise that “very substantially deprived” tenants of quiet enjoyment, even without an intent to evict, directly matching the proposition’s focus on serious interference caused by the landlord’s acts or failures to act.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when there is a serious or substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court explicitly describes the standard for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 in terms of the landlord’s acts or omissions impairing the value of the leased premises, and applies it to serious code violations that substantially affected the apartment’s habitability. Although the opinion emphasizes impairment of value rather than using the exact words "serious or substantial interference," that is the substance of the standard it applies. The case thus supports the proposition that a serious, substantial interference with use and enjoyment caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions breaches the covenant.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises. … A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. … A “landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,” Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716, on the question whether there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when there is a serious or substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” by relying on earlier Massachusetts cases and notes that the covenant protects the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises. It also approves the jury’s finding that repeated flooding “interfered with [the tenant’s] quiet enjoyment” under G.L. c. 186, § 14, based on the landlord’s failure to act—i.e., its omissions—thus tying breach to substantial interference caused by the landlord’s conduct or inaction. This aligns with the stated proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … The jury found in answer to a special question … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”}

Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.raw_text: Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.proposition: A landlord’s failure, after notice, to correct serious housing defects within the landlord’s control, including defects impacting utilities such as electricity, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt from Hemingway is a concurring/dissenting opinion addressing implied warranty of habitability and statutory code‑based obligations, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It discusses tenants’ rent obligations, statutory remedies, and how housing code violations can affect rent liability, but it does not frame a landlord’s failure to repair serious defects (including utilities) as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–03 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s failure, after notice, to correct serious housing defects within the landlord’s control, including defects impacting utilities such as electricity, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the timing of rent abatement when serious defects (lack of heat and hot water) exist after notice. It expressly notes there was insufficient evidence of intentional, negligent, or bad‑faith conduct and does not analyze or apply the covenant of quiet enjoyment at all. While the same facts could, in another case, support a quiet-enjoyment claim, this decision is authority for strict liability under the warranty of habitability, not for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on failure to correct defects affecting utilities.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”
